title: As of 9 May 2020, how many COVID-19 related deaths will have occurred in the U.S. as reported by COVID Tracker?

There are currently 1.18 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 and a little over 68,000 deaths directly attributable to COVID-19 (not just suspected from excess expected death tolls).  According to the CDC, from the week of 3/28/20, which was the first week that total U.S. deaths eclipsed 1,000 deaths, until the week of 4/11/20 when the total number of weekly deaths peaked at around 12,300, the geometric mean of the growth rate of deaths over that three week period was 66%. During that period many of the states instituted quarantines that limited movement and commerce.  Death count fell approximately 75% to 3,200 from the peak by the week of 4/28/2020 as the quarantines began to reduce the preconditions for transmission. Though 35 states have decided to partially pare back those restrictions, the states with highest density, and hence most at risk, have not pared back those restrictions. So, that should contribute to a lower growth rate of infections which curb hospitalizations and deaths attributable to COVID-19.  The effect may be partially mitigated by new diagnoses from the increased availability of testing that makes more excess deaths officially attributable to COVID-19.  While a second upsurge is possible due to the easing of restrictions in some states, the lack of widespread travel, relatively lower population density of those states, and the incubation period of between 7-10 days makes it highly unlikely that a formidable enough upsurge in death counts officially attributable to COVID-19 causes the official CDC death count to exceed 80,000 by May 9.

Looking at weekly movement in deaths based on the latest numbers, it looks between 12 to 14k per week for the last few weeks. Even if that drops to 10k, it will still be in the 70 - 80k range. This assumes there are no big jumps. Previous

May 3rd the tracker has 61,868 deaths. This is lower than other sources I've seen (1point3acres has 68k+). The number goes up 1-2k/day, some days as high as 3k, but split roughly in half between 1k and 2k. May 9th is 6 days away. So we can guess 3 days it'll go up 3k, 3 days it'll go up 6k, that's 9K. Small chance of a 3k day, and that puts it just above 70k pretty much no matter what. I don't expect any surprise revisions in the next 6 days, especially as pressure to open up the economy grows, and further revisions upward would be politically and economically devastating.

As on 2nd May (including 2nd May), the tracker shows 60,700 deaths in the US.  We need to add death data for the next 7 days to answer the question. We can expect approximately 2000 deaths (per weekday) and 1500 deaths over the weekend. Total of 13,000 deaths more till 9th May.  So between 70k and 80k - 90%
     between 60k and 70k -   8%  (rapid drop in deaths)
     between 80k and 90k -   2%  (rapid rise in deaths)

Average deaths per day for the last week: 1800 (200 down from the average over the previous weeks)
To not make the third bracket, the average deaths for next week would need to go below 1400. As daily deaths did not seem to decrease superlinearly in other countries, this seems a bit unlikely (but the data is quite noisy here...)
To go above the bracket, 2800 daily deaths would be necessary, which would require a change in the slight downward trend to a level of deaths consistently above peak. This seems quite unlikely to happen on such a short time frame.
Forecast from extrapolation: 0|15|82|3|0|0
Adjustment for potential change in counting cases: 0|14|80|5|1|0

Continuing this trend would land the deaths at about 75k per 9th May Risk: given discrepancies to other sites (e.g. Johns Hopkins with 66k deaths  https://www.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6)  there is small risk of upward correction

Average daily increase is currently around 3.5%. Even if this increase drops (and hopefully it does), the figure still seems likely to be above 70k. My calcs make it around 76,200.

Ever since COVID began rapidly spreading in the US both numbers of cases and overall deaths have remained pretty linear rising by by about 1-2.5 thousand each day. With ineffective social distancing and reports of much needed PTE as well as already reopening many public domains I don't expect this linear representation of death to start to fall anytime before at least June. At the moment we currently have 63,000 and one would expect there to be about 13-17 thousand deaths in the next nine days. If one is to take non recorded or misdiagnosed COVID deaths this number could be even higher considering the lack of available tests in areas without as high recorded numbers.

The problem in estimating these events is that they relate to events (infections) that occurred 2-3 weeks ago a time when misinformation about the severity of the outbreak was at a peak. The desire of the administration to suppress deaths due to Covid-19 must slant the figures to lower numbers.

I calculated the death count averages for the last 3 weeks, and their standard deviation. I then charted the trend line and it was slight negative over time, with ups and downs. But this downward trend could change with easing of social distance restrictions. If so, the numbers would be higher. My range was between 70,935 and 78,403, which accounted for the downward trend, the average weekly standard deviations for the past 3 weeks.

Deaths are average 1866/day over the last 9 days. Assuming the average remains relatively constant. That projects to 74,060 on May 9.  Deaths may diminish slightly due to improvements in treatment, both through use of remdesivir and a gradually growing understanding of more effective palliative care.
Number of deaths per day is holding steady, but could increase, esp if counties and states start reporting more non-hospital deaths.
The growth of the cumulative number of deaths is slowing down and a 5 parameter logistic model gives 68.000 for May 9th. Unless there is a sudden rise in numbers it should not be above 70.000.
I see states opening up too early.
Deaths continue to rise daily, and states reopening early should continue that trend.

In line with the 78;000 forecast by DELPHI.  Opening up of Southern states won’t have incurred in time to drastically alter the path.  This is a tragedy of significant scale that, according to the preponderance of the evidence I have read, could have been substantially reduced if we had rolled out widespread testing 30 days earlier.  The tip-off to the urgency is the phase “exponential growth”.

Deaths and new confirmed cases have both been increasing linearly over the past three weeks (~30K new cases/day, ~2K deaths/day). If this pattern continues (a reasonable assumption for deaths, since those numbers lag behind new cases), we can expect about 74,000 deaths by May 9. Given the (arguably premature) loosening of restrictions in late April and early May, there is a decent chance that the death rate will increase to the 80,000 range.
On the bubble. The impact of the lockdown is now showing up in fatalities, it just took a long time.
Most of the adjustments from late death tolls have been made, and with May 9th being less than two weeks away, the growth per day will settle into 3% to 4%.

Last two days (Apr 26 and 27) have seen a drop to around 2.3% per day but the week prior was higher with more than double at 4.8%. If the last two days were outliers the figure could be over 80k but hopefully that is not the case.
The trajectory is pointing to steadily to mid 60,000 fatalities
The most recent data points, for April 26 & 27, may be outliers.  But the death rate slowed very significantly for these last two days.  I'll shift from heavily weighting 70-80k towards 60-70k.
Inaccurate testing means we do not have accurate cases vs deaths data - I believe as testing increases the rate of deaths will be less than originally believed.

Used a similar  methodology to what I used on cases. If I look at days in April, 38% of the time it is in the range that would have ended with more than 60k but less than 70k, 54% in the range that is 70k to 80k and 8% in the range that is 80k to 90k. If I do rolling 13 day periods it gets to 7% in the range 60 - 70k, 93% in the range 70 - 80k. Making up the forecast of 45% all days in May, 50% the rolling period and then spreading the other 5% across the buckets without any prob in them anyway. Using all days back to early April probably assumes a bit off a fall off, given numbers have certainly increased in then, but it also just broadens the distribution. Not really willing to call this as part the peak given it not super clear from the data that is the case and we may be seeing in an acceleration in cases, plus evidence lockdown is being relaxed. Probably less probability in the higher numbers than the disease has the capability to deliver, but given this is relatively short term, any broader breakdown in the lockdown restriction is likely to not show up in the data until towards the end of the process.
Assumed a 3-4% linear growth rate to get to ~75k on 5/9. Assumed that any flattening and new cases from reopening will offset each other in the short term.

Dartboard estimate based on current reported rate (50.439) and rate at 04/18/20 (24,555), broad assumption that reasonable to expect death rate to decrease significantly in period to 09/05/20, with some flattening. I am assuming that even if curve-flattening lockdown restrictions are abandoned before that date the real impact of this would be expected further down the line - so as the current restrictions will have had some time to embed by 09/05, I am assuming a flattening even if restrictions are prematurely lifted.
As per 26-April 49k deaths in US with approx. 2000 deaths per day and stable/slightly declining trend (13 days to go)

Added another degree of freedom to fitting (time of start of social distancing).  This makes models with higher death rates a better fit.  Fits with deaths <60k on May 9th are very bad.  Most likely category is still 70-80, but more likely to be higher than lower.

By my projections, there will be roughly 73.000 deaths in the U.S. by May 9th. The growth has been roughly linear for a while, and while the amount of cases may start to flatten, the deaths will (most likely) take more time to follow that trend. It is, however, more likely to fall just shy of 70.000, than that it is to exceed 80.000.
We can reasonably expect a curve flattening to continue, but as states open up we have to consider the possibility of growth.

As of today 4/25, 52,459 deaths have been reported. The day-to-day rate has gotten smaller, yet I expect it to not drop quickly.
A growing number of citizens, and not only the fringe few, are tiring of limitations and are likely to commingle in larger numbers, thereby bringing of the infection rate. That's only two weeks from now and will be an even larger factor after the May 9th forecast date.
More states have been revising their death reports to include a number which were previously unreported or underreported, such as in institutional settings.

Created a tiem series forecasting model

Minimizing error of the fit of the epidemiological model to the historical data as a function of the "social distancing" R value assumed in the model gives a model error vs number of deaths on May 9th.  The overall best fit was with R of 0.95 and predicted May 9th deaths of 70k.  Roughly matched the probabilities in the prediction to the error in the fit when the May 9th deaths are in the center of each category.
Based on a fit to an epidemiological model that predicts 65k on May 9th, but has mostly under-predicted in the past.
I believe IHME  Model mid-range projection has too short a right tail (new deaths fall too quickly).

With a fairly stabilised new case rate, and the lag rate for death Vs detection, I'm assuming about a 2,300 per day avg for the next 2 weeks, being very close to 80k. Also, based on 'recorded numbers': I expect 100,000+ is most likely a true number, but govt even if they know this won't up these official figures.

Nate Silver wrote an interesting piece on FiveThirtyEight.com.  Some states have peaked, but he identifies, as of April 23rd, 18 states plus DC that have not peaked. There are 95 million people living in these states.   If the death rate goes down in some states and up the 18 identified by Silver, then a simple (and admittedly very approximate) way to estimate the trend is to assume its constant for the next few weeks.  If so we'll see around 75000 deaths by May 9th. So while I'm overweighting the 70k to 80k range, I'll be watching the daily data for signs that I'm in the weeds. <https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/coronavirus-cases-are-still-growing-in-many-u-s-states/>. Note: I've noticed that when I put a URL in the comment section it omits the ">" on the right side.  In any case you can navigate to the article pretty easily.
They're behind in reporting deaths. As of 4/24 at 11:45pm, they report 46,204 while the CDC reported 48,816 as of 4/23 and John Hopkins reported 51,017. Using their daily averages for past 7 days.

My logistic model gives relatively tight estimates within the 2nd bucket, even if I take into account potential increase in count by 5,000+ probable deaths now counted by CDC. Others are moving to third bucket. Well, I am sticking to my contrarian spirit... May change it if new data contradicts my conclusions.

I looked at the COVID tracker site and also some projected by day death rates given performance until now.  Based on the models I accessed, the US is looking at around 66k deaths by 9 May.  Now, given the current protests and partial openings of states taking place against health professional's orders, I lowered my probability that we'll stay in that range from 60% to 40% and increased the likelihood that we'll exceed that figure by 10k-20k.
Sourches:
https://www.google.com/search?q=covid+tracker&rlz=1C1CHFX_enUS561US561&oq=covid+tracker&aqs=chrome..69i57j0l6j69i60.1793j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8 https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america

The date is in around 17 days after the most recent tracker update. Over the past 17-18 days there have been around 35k fatalities, so adding this so the current score puts it at around 80k. There is often a lag between cases and fatalities as it takes a few days for the virus to take hold. I.e. People don't die on the day they are diagnosed, but slightly after. The lag on case results and deaths is similar. There appears to be a consistent or even slight increase in cases currently, meaning that the rate of fatalities will also potentially remain the same. Variables include the potential for more non hospital deaths to get counted (making the total higher) or for more testing inflating the infection growth rate making the projection worse than it is (so fewer deaths)

Using a similar model [1] and methodology [2] as I used for the current weekly question [3]. In short, it does the following: 1. Projects linearly based on declining growth slope since (what looks like) the peak on Fri, Apr 14th
2. Adjusts for day of week variation - there's clear day-of-week variation where counts on Sat/Sun/Mon/Tue are lower than expected if following a perfect linear slope, and counts on Wed/Thu/Fri are higher than expected. See graph on model spreadsheet.
3. Calculates a standard deviation around the projected mean by taking the projected count minus today's count and dividing by 6 May 9th Forecast: 68,244 The biggest risk here is that the COVID Tracking Project will adjust their counting methodology to include probable deaths per new CDC guidelines, which could cause a big spike in counts. However, there's some evidence that it might be seen as politically-charged to do so, so perhaps less likely. See more discussion on this topic here [4]. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1348526407
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1020137
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1599-how-many-total-cases-of-covid-19-in-the-u-s-will-the-covid-tracking-project-report-as-of-sunday-26-april-2020
[4] https://www.metaculus.com/questions/4187/lrt-12-as-of-saturday-may-9-2020-how-many-covid-19-related-deaths-will-have-occurred-in-the-us/#comment-28515

The US deaths appear to have peak around 16 April.  This peak appeared about 3 weeks from the start of significant impacts on Workplace Mobility as shown in the Google Mobility Reports [1].   With the slowing down of the outbreak, it is appropriate to apply a logistic model to the data.  From the logistic model, the total deaths on 9 May are 64562, in the middle of the second basket. [1]  https://www.google.com/covid19/mobility/
Trending linearly to 75K, but it appears that daily death rates may be plateauing.

5% growth rate for deaths every 4 days puts it under 60000 or 51816. Redid it with 4% growth rate in cases overall and a 5.6% death rate for US. Came out to 57207. Perhaps the difference between 5 and 5.6. https://coronavirus.1point3acres.com/

Cases peaked between April 4 and April 10 and have been declining at a rate of 2.7 %.  April 21st saw the highest number of deaths in one day at 2804 (worldometer; 2674 Covid tracker).  Calculating a decline of 2.7% from that peak over 16 days gives a cumulative total of 79699. Doing the same calculation with yesterdays total of 2108 (Covid tracker; 2341 worldometer) provides a cumulative total of 70367.
